G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the matter in controversy does not exceed $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the Defendant’s grocery store where the incident occurred is located within this Court’s jurisdiction.

*Schwartz v. Honeywell Int\u2019l, Inc.*.raw_text: *Schwartz v. Honeywell Int’l, Inc.*, 102 Mass. App. Ct. 1056 (2022).
*Schwartz v. Honeywell Int\u2019l, Inc.*.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, owners and operators of businesses owe a duty of care to lawful visitors on their premises, including a duty to maintain their property in a reasonably safe condition and to remedy or warn of known hazards.

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 785 (2007).
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.proposition: The Defendant had actual notice of the hazardous condition, as the employee explicitly stated he had observed the spill but made the conscious decision to delay addressing it.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: The case does not involve any evidence that a specific employee actually saw the grape on the floor and chose to delay cleaning it up. Instead, the decision focuses on adopting the mode-of-operation doctrine and holds that the store had notice of the general, inherent risks created by its self-service operation, not actual notice of this particular spill. The proposition mischaracterizes the opinion by turning generalized notice of risk into explicit, employee-level actual notice of the hazardous condition.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt: “Under the mode of operation approach, the plaintiff’s burden to prove notice is not eliminated. Instead, the plaintiff satisfies the notice requirement if he establishes that an injury was attributable to a reasonably foreseeable dangerous condition on the owner’s premises that is related to the owner’s self-service mode of operation… [T]he owner of such a self-service establishment has actual notice that his mode of operation creates certain risks of harm to his customers.”

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973).
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: The Defendant also had constructive notice of the hazard, given that the puddle had existed for a sufficient duration to have cart tracks running through it.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The case discusses constructive notice and the need to show that a foreign substance existed for a sufficient time to be discovered, but it ultimately finds the evidence insufficient and orders judgment for the defendant. There is no mention of cart tracks or similar indicia of duration, and the court expressly holds that the circumstantial evidence presented (including the hard, adherent substance) did not establish the required time element. Thus, the opinion does not support the proposition that constructive notice was established based on marks or tracks in a puddle.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: "The issue presented is whether the evidence is sufficient to permit a jury to infer that the substance had been on the step long enough so that in the exercise of reasonable care the defendant should have discovered and removed it... There is nothing to distinguish this case from the great majority of cases in which we have held that directed verdicts were required. The mere stickiness or adherence of the substance to the step is not such a quality as, in common knowledge, established the time element... Judgment for the defendant."

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: This breach of duty resulted in foreseeable harm, as customers like the Plaintiff could reasonably be expected to traverse the dairy aisle.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns foreseeability of harm to store customers traversing a specific interior area (the dairy aisle). Papadopoulos addresses a different context: a customer slipping on ice in an outdoor parking lot, and the court’s abolition of the natural/unnatural snow and ice distinction in premises liability. While the case discusses general foreseeability and reasonable care to lawful visitors, it does not speak to customers traversing particular interior store aisles or use such an example, so it does not specifically support the stated proposition.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice, or rust on a railing, or a discarded banana peel, the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.” (457 Mass. at 383)

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: The Defendant’s negligence was the sole and proximate cause of the Plaintiff’s injuries, as the hazard created by the spilled milk would not have injured the Plaintiff absent the Defendant’s failure to act.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The case does not discuss spilled milk, a hazard created by the defendant, or a finding that the defendant’s negligence was the sole proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. Instead, the Massachusetts SJC holds that Westwood owed no duty to alter the state highway and thus could not be liable in negligence at all, and it also rejects vicarious liability. This opinion therefore undermines, rather than supports, a proposition that defendant’s negligence was the sole and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries from a particular hazard.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: "Before liability for negligence can be imposed, there must first be a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, and a breach of that duty proximately resulting in the injury... In this case, Westwood did not fail to exercise reasonable care in the use of its land, nor was there any condition on its land that created an unreasonable risk to users of Route 1A... To hold that Westwood owed the plaintiff such a duty would significantly expand the scope of a landowner or possessor’s duties... This we decline to do."
